questions.text: Which of the below is an example of effective learning?

options.label: C
options.text: Motivating a person for blood donation

questions.correct_answer: C. Motivating a person for blood donation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Motivating a person for blood donation Assessment of learning domains to improve student learning in higher education. Journal of Young Pharmacists Vol. 6. Issue 4 Jan-Mar 2014 Bloom’s taxonomy divides the educational objectives into three domains Cognitive domain: It focuses on intellectual skills. Psychomotor domain: It focuses on performing sequences of motor activities to a specified level of accuracy, smoothness, rapidity, or force. Affective domain: It causes attitude, motivation, willingness to participate, valuing what is being learned, and ultimately incorporating the discipline values into real life.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of Various components of the ‘communication process:
questions.correct_answer: C. Sender, Message, Channel, Receiver, Feedback
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sender, Message, Channel, Receiver, Feedback Communication process: the process of exchanging ideas, feelings, and information Components of the communication process: Sender (source) Receiver (audience) Message (content) Channel(s) (medium) Feedback (effect)

questions.correct_answer: A. All information must be given, except expected complications, as the patient may get frightened
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All information must be given, except expected complications, as the patient may get frightened ICMR 2006 Informed Consent of Participants In all biomedical research involving human participants, informed consent of the participant or legal guardian (in case the participant is incapable of giving informed consent) is a must. Adequate information on the research in a simple and easily understandable unambiguous language is given in the Informed Consent Form with Participant/Patient Information Sheet containing the following information. Nature and Purpose of Study Duration of participation with several participants Procedures to be followed Investigations, if any, are to be performed. Foreseeable risks and discomforts whether the project involves more than minimal risk Benefits to participant, community, or medical profession Policy on Compensation Availability of medical treatment for such injuries or risk management Alternative therapies, if available Steps being taken to ensure confidentiality No loss of benefits on withdrawal Benefit sharing in the event of commercialization
